title: Paris
description:
Paris is the capital city of France. It is situated on the River Seine, in northern France, at the heart of the Île-de-France region. Paris has an estimated population of 2,153,600 within its administrative limits. The Paris unité urbaine is an area of unbroken urban growth that extends well beyond the administrative city limits, with a population of 9.93 million. Paris commuter belt area, or couronne périurbaine, when joined with Paris and its unité urbaine, completes the Paris aire urbaine that, with its population of 12 million, is one of the most heavily populated areas in Europe.
An important settlement for more than two millennia, Paris is today one of the world's leading business and cultural centres, and its influence in politics, education, entertainment, media, fashion, science and the arts all contribute to its status as one of the world's major global cities. The Paris Region is France's foremost centre of economic activity. With €500.8 billion, it produced more than a quarter of the gross domestic product (GDP) of France in 2006. The Paris Region hosts 36 of the Fortune Global 500 companies in several business districts, notably La Défense, the largest purpose-built business district in Europe. Paris also hosts many international organizations such as UNESCO, the OECD, the ICC and the informal Paris Club.
Its historic City Hall is near the center of the city.
http://www.wikimapia.org/45237/H%C3%B4tel-de-Ville-Paris-City-Hall
and the historic center island
http://www.wikimapia.org/1420371/Ile-de-la-Cite

Paris is the most popular tourist destination in the world, with over 30 million foreign visitors per year. There are numerous iconic landmarks among its many attractions, along with world famous institutions and popular parks.
http://en.parisinfo.com/
http://paris.360cities.net/
http://www.paris.fr/english
http://wiki.worldflicks.org/paris.html
http://www.paris-26-gigapixels.com/index-en.html
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Raru9qRLG9M

title: 15th arrondissement
description:
located on the Left Bank, the most populous of the 20 arrondissements of Paris.
It shares the Montparnasse district with the 6th and 14th arrondissements

title: 13th arrondissement (Gobelins)
description: located on the Left Bank. It is home to Paris's main Chinatown,  also hosts the Bibliothèque François Mitterrand and the newly built business district of Paris Rive Gauche

title: 19th arrondissement (Buttes Chaumonts)
description:
located on the Right Bank, crossed by two canals, the Canal Saint-Denis and the Canal de l'Ourc.
Contains the Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie, which is an exhibition center dedicated to sciences and industries, and the Cité de la Musique.

title: 18th arrondissement (Butte Montmartre)
description: The 18th arrondissement (XVIIIe arrondissement), located on the Rive Droite (Right Bank), is one of the 20 arrondissements of Paris, France. It is mostly known for hosting the district of Montmartre, which contains a hill dominated by the Sacré Coeur basilica, as well as the famous Moulin Rouge.

title: 20th arrondissement (Ménilmontat)
description: located on the Right Bank, contains the cosmopolitan districts of Ménilmontant and Belleville.

title: 14th arrondissement (Observatoire)
description:
located on the Left Bank and contains most of the Montparnasse district.
The district is today best-known for its skyscraper, the Tour Montparnasse, and its national rail station, the Gare Montparnasse.

title: 17th arrondissement (Batignolles)
description:
The 17th arrondissement (XVIIe arrondissement), located on the Right Bank, is one of the 20 arrondissements of Paris, France. 

This arrondissement hosts two very active areas: 
in the northern part, the working-class area around Place de Clichy is an extension of the Pigalle red-light district.
in the southern part, the upper-class area around Avenue des ternes, where the Marché Poncelet is located.

title: 7th arrondissement (Palais de Bourbon)
description: The 7th district of Paris includes many major tourist attractions including the Eiffel tower, National Assembly, Les Invalides (Military museum), the Orsay Museum, the Rodin Museum, the Quai Branly Museum, Egouts de Paris.

title: 8th arrondissement (Elysèe)
description: hosts many places of interest, such as the Champs-Élysées, the Élysée Palace, the Arc de Triomphe and Place de la Concorde.

title: 11th arrondissement (Popincourt)
description: The most densely populated of the 20 arrondissements of Paris.

title: 10th arrondissement (Enclos-St-Laurent)
description: Contains two of the six main rail stations in Paris: Gare du Nord and Gare de l'Est, and a large portion of the Canal Saint-Martin,

title: 5th arrondissment (Panthèon)
description: The 5th district includes much of the Latin Quarter. It has been populated since Roman times. The present day rue St. Jacques follows the path of the Roman road. Beneath the Museum of the Middle Ages in the Hotel Cluny, Roman baths have been excavated. A Roman arena can also be found here.

title: Montmartre
description: Montmartre is a hill (the butte Montmartre) which is 129 metres high, giving its name to the surrounding district, in the north of Paris in the 18th arrondissement, a part of the Right Bank. Montmartre is primarily known for the white-domed Basilica of the Sacré Cœur on its summit and as a nightclub district.

title: 9th arrondissement (Opèra)
description: located around the Opéra, includes the Boulevard Haussmann and its large department stores Galeries Lafayette and Printemps.

title: 6th arrondissement (Luxembourg)
description:
Located on the Left Bank. It is well known for the district of Saint-Germain-des-Prés which is dominated by its Abbey. It includes some of what is known as the Latin Quarter. It is home to the French Senate.
It has its own City Hall. See
http://www.wikimapia.org/4045968/City-hall-of-the-6th-arrondissement-of-Paris

title: Montrouge
description: a commune in the southern suburbs of Paris

title: Malakoff
description: a commune in the southwestern suburbs of Paris

title: 1st arrondissement (Louvre)
description: The 1st arrondissement (district) is located on the Right Bank and the west end of the Île de la Cité. It is the historic center of Paris and includes some of the most important tourist attractions including the Louvre and the Tuileries Gardens.

title: 4th arrondissement (Hotel de Ville)
description: Located on the Right Bank, contains the Pompidou Centre, the Notre Dame and the southern lively part of the medieval district of Le Marais.

title: Le Marais
description:
Le Marais (meaning "the marsh" in French) is a district in Paris, France, traditionally a bourgeois area, but also well-known historically. It spreads across parts of the 3rd and 4th arrondissements in Paris (on the Rive Droite, or Right Bank, of the Seine).

Reading recommendations:

A Town Like Paris: Falling in Love in the City of Light - http://www.itravellibrary.com/book/detail/A-Town-Like-Paris-Falling-in-Love-in-the-City-of-Light/0767928172

title: Latin Quarter
description:
The Latin Quarter of Paris is an area in the 5th arrondissement and parts of the 6th arrondissement of Paris, on the south side of the Seine, around the Sorbonne University.

The name derives from the Latin language, which was widely spoken in the Middle Ages in and around the University.

It currently still houses various higher education establishments, such as the École Normale Supérieure, the École des Mines de Paris (a ParisTech institute) and the Jussieu university campus. Other establishments such as the École Polytechnique (also a ParisTech engineering school) have relocated to more spacious settings.

title: 3rd arrondissement (Temple)
description: Located on the Right Bank, contains the northern more quiet part of the medieval district of Le Marais.

description: Délimitation du quartier Didot/Porte de Vanves selon la définition du conseil de quartier du même nom. title: 2nd arrondissement (Bourse)
description: Located on the right bank of the River Seine, the 2nd arrondissement hosts an important business district

title: La Villette
description: It is a Park containing in particular several showrooms and concert halls, including the Zenith (up to 5000 seats)

title: La Seine
description: Les deux rives de la Seine sont inscrites sur la liste du patrimoine mondial de l'UNESCO depuis 1991.

title: Quartier Pigalle
description: Famous area in Paris around Place Pigalle, on the border between the 9th and the 18th arrondissements. It is named after the sculptor Jean-Baptiste Pigalle (1714–1785).

title: Père Lachaise Cemetery
description:
6 Rue Du Repos
Paris, ÎLE-DE-FRANCE 75020, FR

http://www.pere-lachaise.com

Père-Lachaise Cemetery (French: Cimetière du Père-Lachaise) (officially, cimetière de l'Est “eastern cemetery”) (48°51′43″N, 2°23′39″E) is the largest cemetery in the city of Paris, France at 118 acres[1] (48 ha), though there are larger cemeteries in Paris suburbs.

Père-Lachaise is one of the most famous in the world. Located in the 20e arrondissement, it is reputed to be the world's most-visited cemetery, attracting hundreds of thousands of visitors annually to the graves of those who have enhanced French life over the past 200 years. It is also the site of five Great War memorials.

Père-Lachaise is located on Boulevard de Ménilmontant. Métro station Philippe Auguste on line 2 is next to the main entrance, while the station called Père Lachaise, on lines 2 or 3, is 500 metres away near a side entrance. (Many tourists are reported to prefer the Gambetta station on line 3 as it allows them to enter near the tomb of Oscar Wilde and go downhill to visit the rest of the cemetery.)

Contents [hide]
1 Origins 
2 Burials at Père-Lachaise 
3 Gallery 
4 References 
5 External links 

[edit] Origins
The cemetery takes its name from Père François de la Chaise (1624-1709), the confessor of Louis XIV, who lived in the Jesuit house rebuilt in 1682 on the site of the chapel. The property, situated on the hillside (from which the king, during the Fronde, watched skirmishing between the Condé and Turenne) was bought by the city in 1804, laid out by Alexandre-Théodore Brongniart, and later extended.

The cemetery was established by Napoleon in 1804. Cemeteries had been banned inside Paris in 1786, after the closure of the Cimetière des Innocents on the fringe of Les Halles food market, on the grounds that it presented a health hazard. (This same health hazard also led to the creation of the famous Parisian catacombs in the south of the city). Several new cemeteries replaced all the Parisian ones, outside the precincts of the capital, Montmartre Cemetery in the north, Père-Lachaise in the east, and Montparnasse Cemetery in the south. At the heart of the city, in the shadow of the Eiffel Tower, is Passy Cemetery.

 
Composite image of the tomb of Abélard et Héloïse and various detailsAt the time of its opening, the cemetery was seen as too far from the city and attracted few funerals. So the administrators devised a marketing strategy and with great fanfare organised the transfer of the remains of La Fontaine and Molière, in 1804. Then, in another great spectacle in 1817, the purported remains of Pierre Abélard and Héloïse were also transferred to the cemetery with their monument's canopy made from fragments of the abbey of Nogent-sur-Seine (by tradition, lovers or lovelorn singles leave letters at the crypt in tribute to the couple or in hope of finding true love) (see disputation).

This strategy had the desired effect when people began clamouring to be buried among the famous citizens. Records show that, within a few years, Père-Lachaise went from a few dozen permanent residents to more than 33,000. Today there are over 300,000 bodies buried there, and many more in the columbarium, which holds the remains of those who had requested cremation.

The Communards' Wall (Mur des Fédérés) is also located in the cemetery. This is the wall against which 147 Communards, the last defenders of the workers' district Belleville, were shot on Sunday, 28 May 1871—the last day of the "Bloody Week" (Semaine Sanglante) ending the Paris Commune.

 
The monument honouring the French Brigadists.Since that execution, Père Lachaise gained a special emotive role for the political "left" in France, manifested in annual processions sometimes drawing tens or even or hundreds of thousands of participants (some 600,000 in 1936) and led by the main leaders of the left parties and organizations (see article on the Communards' Wall).

Various prominent left-wing leaders are buried in the vicinity, where a monument was also erected honouring the French Brigadists (volunteers in the International Brigades in the Spanish Civil War).

Inspired Mount Auburn Cemetery in Boston, USA, which in turn inspired Abney Park Cemetery, Stoke Newington, London

title: "Chinatown"
description: One of the 2 large Chinese and East Asian neighborhood in Paris, the other one is in Belleville. it is so nice

Saint-Germain-des-Prés
description: Home to a number of famous cafés, such as Les Deux Magots and Le Café de Flore, where artists, writers and philosophers would meet, Saint-Germain-des-Prés area used to be the center of gravity for surrealists painters and writers (André Breton especially) in the 1920s and 1930s, then headquarters of existentialists Jean-Paul Sartre and Simone de Beauvoir in the 1950s and 1960s.

title: Cité Internationale Universitaire de Paris
description:
The "Cité Internationale Universitaire de Paris" -- at 17 boulevard Jourdan, 75014 Paris, t. (0)1.44.16.64.00 -- maintains 39 library locations, of which this is the central and largest. It offers 50,000 volumes, 500 periodicals titles, Internet access, and a user-friendly study atmosphere for visiting "foreign" students.

title: Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital
description: The Pitié-Salpêtrière Hospital (Groupe hospitalier de la Pitié-Salpétrière) is a world-renowned teaching hospital located in Paris, France. Part of the Assistance publique - Hôpitaux de Paris, it is one of Europe's largest hospitals.

title: Garden of the Tuileries
description: The oldest public garden in Paris.  Before its destruction (by arson during the 1871 Communard insurrection) the Palace of the Tuileries was located here.

title: Montparnasse Cemetery
description:
Montparnasse Cemetery (French: Cimetière de Montparnasse) is a famous cemetery in the Montparnasse quarter of Paris, part of the city's 14th arrondissement. Created from three farms in 1824, the cemetery at Montparnasse was originally known as Le Cimetière du Sud. 

Montparnasse Cemetery is the eternal home of many of France's intellectual and artistic elite as well as publishers and others who promoted the works of authors and artists. There are also monuments to police and firefighters killed in the line of duty in the city of Paris. Because of the many notable people buried there, it is a highly popular tourist attraction.

http://www.biosstars.com/cimetiere/montparnasse.htm

title: Champ de Mars
description: A Large garden between the Eiffel Tower and the Ecole Militaire (military school). It used to be wider, but was thinned down. It was also the marching ground for students at the Ecole Militaire. Before it's thinning down, Gustave Eiffel, creator of the nearby tower, used to land dirigibles on it.

title: Butte aux cailles
description:
Plus d'infos sur un blog de la Butte aux Cailles :
www.parisbutteauxcailles.com/

title: Parc Montsouris
description: Parc Montsouris is a public city park of Paris, in the 14th arrondissement, in Rive Gauche (the southern portion of the city proper). The park is 15 hectares in area and is designed in the style of an English garden, which was popular at the end of the 19th century. The park was created by Napoleon III and Baron Haussmann as part of a plan to add green areas to Paris. (Wikipedia)

title: Trocadero
description: The Trocadéro, site of the Palais de Chaillot, is an area of Paris, in the 16th arrondissement, across the Seine from the Eiffel Tower. The hill of the Trocadéro is the hill of Chaillot, a former village.

title: Les Invalides
description:
http://www.invalides.org/pages/menu.html
Les Invalides in Paris, France consists of a complex of buildings in the 7th arrondissement containing museums and monuments to France's military history and a necropolis. It is the burial site for some of France's war heroes. Napoleon's remains were buried under the dome.  It was originally designed as well as a hospital and a retirement home for war veterans.

title: Centre hospitalier Sainte-Anne
description: http://www.ch-sainte-anne.fr

title: Campus de Jussieu
description: One of the campuses of the Pierre and Marie Curie University (Université Pierre et Marie Curie or UPMC, formerly Paris 6), principal inheritor of the Faculty of Sciences of the University of Paris  and of Paris 7, the Denis Diderot University (Université Paris 7 - Denis Diderot)

title: École Militaire.
description:
The École Militaire is a vast complex of buildings housing various military teaching facilities located in Paris, France, southeast of the Champ de Mars.

It was founded by Louis XV in 1750 on the basis of a proposal of the financier Joseph Pâris (known as Duverney) with the support of Madame de Pompadour, with the aim of creating an academic college for cadet officers from poor families. It was designed by Ange-Jacques Gabriel, and construction began in 1752 on the grounds of the farm of Grenelle, but the school did not open until 1760.

title: Olympiades
description: Grand quartier résidentiel + station de métro dans le 13e arrondissement de Paris

title: Gare Montparnasse
description:
A terminus station in Paris. It is the start of the TGV lines to Rennes, Tours, Nantes and Bordeaux. The station was built in 1840 but soon replaced 8 years later. In 1969, the station was resited to the south at its current position and a new building was built along with an office block. In the 1990s it saw expansion for the TGV.

The station had a famous accident in 1895 when a Granville Express failed to stop due to brake failure, and crashed through the buffers. The train shot across the concourse and smashed through the façade. The locomotive plummeted into Place de Rennes, and was left standing on its nose. Despite the spectacular scene, only one person (a woman on the street) was killed and 5 people on the train injured.

During the liberation of Paris, a German General Dietrich von Choltitz was ordered by Hitler to cause as much damage to Paris as possible before the Allies liberated it. Choltitz had been loyal to Hitler and had authorised destruction in Holland and Paris (including the Grand Palais), but Choltitz refused and made his surrender to General Leclerc inside the old station.

title: Cimetière de Montmartre
description:
Nord cemetery, known as Montmartre cemetery.

Paris Cemeteries: http://www.pariscemeteries.com/pagecems/montmar.html

title: Île Saint-Louis
description: The Île Saint-Louis (French pronunciation: [il sɛ̃ lwi]) is one of two natural islands in the Seine river, in Paris, France (the other natural island is Île de la Cité, the Île aux Cygnes is artificial). The island is named after King Louis IX of France (Saint Louis).

title: Gare de Lyon
description: Paris Lyon (or Gare de Lyon) is one of the six large railway termini in Paris, France. It is the northern terminus of the Paris–Marseille railway. It is named after the city of Lyon, a stop for many long-distance trains departing here, most en route to the south of France. In general the station's SNCF services run to the south and east of France. The station also hosts regional trains and the RER. It is served by the Gare de Lyon metro station. The station is located in the XIIe arrondissement, on the north bank of the river Seine, east of Paris.

title: Planted promenade
description: " Planted promenade ", 4 km promenade which borrows the line of the old line of railway of Vincennes, traffic of which ceased in 1969.

title: Le quartier Masséna
description: Ce quartier occupe l'ancien emplacement des usines Panhard-Levassor. Les tours donnent de plain-pied sur la rue et sont bien intégrées dans le tissu urbain. Elles portent des noms de compositeurs ou de villes italiennes : Puccini, Palerme, Rimini.

title: Parc Monceau
description:
Parc Monceau (/paʁk mɔ̃.sɔ/) is a public park situated in the 8th and 17th Arrondissements of Paris at the junction of Boulevard de Courcelles, Rue de Prony and Rue Georges Berger. At the main entrance is a rotunda (see photo).

The park was established by Phillippe d'Orléans, Duke of Chartres, a cousin of the king. He started buying land on which to establish the garden in 1769, and employed Louis Carrogis Carmontelle to design the gardens. He was a close friend of the Prince of Wales, later George IV, and a lover of all things English. As a result, his aim was to create an informal English-style garden in the middle of Paris. By 1778, through successive purchases, the garden had grown to 12 hectares. It became known as the Folie de Chartres.

title: Parc Georges Brassens
description: One of the larger parks in the 15ème arrondissement, named after the famous French singer.

title: Hopital Saint-Louis
description: full service hospital including emergency and pediatrics.

title: Gare d'Austerlitz - Austerlitz Station
description: Gare d'Austerlitz is one of the six major train stations in Paris, France. It is the terminus of the line to Toulouse, and is located on the opposite side of the river to the Gare de Lyon.

title: Hopital Necker
description:
This is a large Paris hospital specialising in paediatrics ( childrens medicine.)
http://www.necker.fr/

title: Complexe Sportif Georges Carpentier
description: Complexe Sportif Georges Carpentier

title: Le Louvre
description:
The Louvre Museum (Musée du Louvre or Le Louvre) is the largest museum in Paris by its surface: 210 000 square metres of which 60 600 devoted to exhibitions. It is one of the oldest in the world, and the third in terms of area. The Louvre is the most visited museum in the world, with 8.3 million visitors in 2006.
The building is a former royal palace, the Palais du Louvre.
Universalist Museum, the Louvre covers a wide chronology  and  geographical area, from antiquity to 1848, Western Europe to Iran, via Greece, Egypt and the Near East. The works are of a varied nature: paintings, sculptures, drawings, ceramics, archaeological objects and objects of art ...
Among the most famous of the museum are the Code of Hammurabi, the Venus de Milo, Mona Lisa by Leonardo da Vinci, and Liberty leading the people of Eugène Delacroix.

title: Gare de l'Est
description: The Gare de l'Est (East Station) in Paris a railway station in Paris serving the east of France, Switzerland, Germany and other parts of Europe. Suburban traffic has been reduced by the RER but Intercity traffic has increased with the recent TGV line opened.

title: Stade Sebastien Charlety
description: Stade Sebastien Charlety is a multi-use stadium in Paris, France. It is currently used mostly for rugby league matches. Officially, the capacity of the stadium is currently 20,000 people. The stadium opened in 1938. It hosted many matches in various Rugby League World Cups.

title: Ménagerie du Jardin des Plantes
description: The Ménagerie du Jardin des Plantes is a zoo in Paris, France, belonging to the botanical garden Jardin des Plantes. It is the second oldest zoo in the world.

title: Val-de-Grâce
description:
The Val-de-Grâce (Hôpital d'instruction des armées du Val-de-Grâce or HIA Val-de-Grâce) is a military hospital located in the 5th arrondissement of Paris, France.
The church of the Val-de-Grâce was built by order of Queen Anne of Austria, wife of Louis XIII. After the birth of her son Louis XIV, Anne (previously childless after 23 years of marriage) showed her gratitude to the Virgin Mary by building a church on the land of a Benedictine convent. Louis XIV himself is said to have laid the cornerstone for the Val-de-Grâce in a ceremony that took place April 1, 1645, when he was seven years old.

title: Hôpital Cochin, Paris 14e
description:
Groupe hospitalier Cochin - Saint-Vincent de Paul.
Groupement hospitalier universitaire Ouest. 

http://membres.lycos.fr/radiobcochin/hopital.htm
http://www.aphp.fr/index.php?module=portail&action=afficherPortail&vue=portail&NIHOPITAL=9

title: Ancienne île Louviers
description: L'île Louviers, appelée aussi île aux Javiaux, était une île de la Seine à Paris, en France, qui fut rattachée à la berge au XIXe siècle.
